{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3390747,"name":"Micah Doberne-Schor","username":"BouncingBuilder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/a698b9/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-22T22:45:08.744Z","cooked":"

FYI we don’t plan to actually build this at all.
What if someone was to create a drivetrain that was swerve but the wheels were also Omni wheels. Sure any odometry would be messed up and there would be absolutely no stopping without hitting another object but it would be a drift machine for sure.
CD, I’m curious about your opinions and thoughts on this insane idea.

Some teams have intentionally installed omni wheels onto malfunctioning or broken swerve modules to survive through a match, taking advantage of the coasting behavior to allow that module to glide under the power of the other modules.

It’s all the disadvantages of omni wheels with the added complexity of swerve drive! get yours today for only 399.99 per module!

Batteries not included. Not for children under 3. May cause cancer or reproductive harm in the state of California. Seek a doctor if developing hives, these may be life threatening. Side effects include nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, stroke, seizure, demonic possession, and death.

I was actually thinking about this too. Couldn’t you use the omni wheels as a CVT by angling them to get variable drive ratios and faster acceleration?

If you were to run your sweve in a x-drive configuration with omniwheels: the losses of contact patch with the carpet vs colsons or rough top would more than likely cancel out the benefits entirely, likely to such an extent you would be worse off.
